metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (No.2 runoff observation system of 312 bridge on the Heihe River, 2015)
metadata.description:
The data set includes the river level observation data of point 2 in the dense runoff observation of the middle reaches of Heihe River from January 1, 2015 to December 31, 2015. The observation point is located in Heihe bridge, 312 National Road, Zhangye City, Gansu Province. The riverbed is sandy gravel with unstable section. The longitude and latitude of the observation point are n38.996667 °, e100.427222 °, altitude 1485m, river width 70m and 20m. Sr50 ultrasonic range finder is used for water level observation, with acquisition frequency of 30 minutes. The data includes the following parts:            
Water level observation, observation frequency 30 minutes, unit (CM);            
In 2015, the section of bridge no.2-312 was frequently disturbed by human beings. The dam was built within 1km of the upstream and downstream of the section. The unstable area of the hydrological section led to the disorder of the water level and flow curve. During the measurement, the stable flow and water level curve could not be obtained.            
The observation of water level is based on the manual observation of water level at 0:00 on January 1, 2015. In the later stage, the hydrological section of river undercut changes. The result is that the datum water level changes and negative value appears;            
Refer to Li et al. (2013) for hydrometeorological network or station information, and he et al. (2016) for observation data processing

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'multiscale observations' mean in the context of eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: In the context of eco-hydrological research, 'multiscale observations' refer to collecting data across different spatial and temporal scales to comprehensively understand eco-hydrological processes. This approach involves using a variety of instruments and techniques to capture data on different scales, such as flux observation matrices, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing technologies, to address the challenge of upscaling these processes in heterogeneous environments.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'eddy covariance system' in measuring energy and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert areas?
Definition.Answer: The 'eddy covariance system' is significant in measuring energy and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert areas as it provides half-hourly turbulent flux data that are crucial for understanding the exchange of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane between the land surface and the atmosphere. This system helps in capturing the dynamics of these exchanges, which are essential for understanding ecological stability and supporting sustainable development in these regions.

Definition.Question: What does 'data quality control' entail in the context of hydrological and meteorological datasets?
Definition.Answer: In the context of hydrological and meteorological datasets, 'data quality control' entails a series of processes designed to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the collected data. This includes sensor calibration, careful data collection, processing, and archiving. It ensures that the datasets generated are of high quality, which is critical for their effective use in research and decision-making.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for water level observation using SR50 ultrasonic sensors compare to the eddy covariance system and scintillometer methods for measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes?
Comparison.Answer: The SR50 ultrasonic sensors are used for water level observation with a 30-minute frequency, focusing on hydrological metrics in river systems. In contrast, the eddy covariance system and scintillometer methods are used to measure energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, capturing ecological and atmospheric interactions, with a high temporal resolution of half-hourly data.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data collection can be inferred from the need for multiscale observations in eco-hydrological processes?
Interpretation.Answer: The need for multiscale observations in eco-hydrological processes suggests challenges such as the difficulty in capturing comprehensive data across different spatial and temporal scales. This is due to the complex interactions within heterogeneous surfaces, as highlighted by the poor availability of multiscale observations that hinder progress in the field.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in obtaining stable flow-stage curves in river hydrological observations, particularly in areas with frequent human disturbances?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in obtaining stable flow-stage curves are primarily due to frequent human disturbances such as dam construction within 1 km of the measurement site, which cause instability in the stream cross-section area.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the availability of multiscale observations considered insufficient for understanding eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The insufficiency of multiscale observations arises because capturing eco-hydrological processes requires instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, which has historically been lacking, thereby hindering progress in understanding these processes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes instability in the baseline water level measurements in river hydrological studies over time?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Instability in baseline water level measurements can occur due to changes in river channel morphology, such as riverbed incision, which alters the hydrological cross-section and subsequently affects the measurement baseline.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of frequent human disturbances on hydrological data collection methods in river channels?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Frequent human disturbances in river channels, such as construction within the vicinity of observation points, lead to instability in hydrological cross-sectional areas. This causes disruptions in water level-flow curves, making it challenging to obtain stable data for hydrological observations.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the hierarchical nesting of observation instruments impact the quality and comprehensiveness of eco-hydrological datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Hierarchical nesting of observation instruments allows for the capture of multiscale eco-hydrological processes, leading to the generation of comprehensive datasets. This setup includes a variety of instruments such as eddy covariance towers, scintillometers, and remote sensing tools, which together enhance the quality and breadth of data collected across different landscape types.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the effect of integrating multiscale and multidisciplinary data on understanding oasis-desert interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiscale and multidisciplinary data facilitates a nuanced understanding of oasis-desert interactions by providing detailed insights into energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes. This integrated approach supports the ecological security and sustainable development of oasis systems by offering a quantitative understanding of these interactions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to establish a sparse network to investigate oasis-desert interactions in eco-hydrological studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Establishing a sparse network enables capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes by arranging instruments in hierarchically nested scales, thus addressing the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations in the field.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis-desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to achieve a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas, which is crucial for recognizing oasis-desert interactions and supporting ecological stability and sustainable socioeconomic development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to implement intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations in eco-hydrological research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Intensive observation periods and continuous observations help overcome the challenge of insufficient multiscale data, allowing researchers to capture comprehensive eco-hydrological processes and interactions within oasis-desert systems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental and procedural steps are involved in setting up an eco-hydrological sensor network to capture multiscale and multidisciplinary data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Procedural steps include arranging instruments in hierarchically nested scales, establishing a sparse network to investigate ecosystem interactions, and constructing superstations and automatic meteorological stations in diverse landscapes. Instruments like eddy covariance towers, scintillometers, and airborne remote sensing tools such as LiDAR and imaging spectrometers are used to capture data at multiple scales.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to address challenges in maintaining stable hydrological measurements in areas with frequent human disturbances affecting riverbed conditions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Procedures involve using instruments like SR50 ultrasonic distance meters for water level observation, understanding changes in hydrological cross-section due to human disturbances, and adjusting measurement baselines when the riverbed conditions change. Frequent calibration and data validation are necessary to account for these instabilities.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of hierarchically nested scales for instrumentation, including the flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing with LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer, enables the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in arid regions.

Enablement.Question: What methods are used to ensure the quality control of hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: Methods used to ensure the quality control of hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert systems include careful sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. These steps are crucial for maintaining the integrity and reliability of data collected over long-term periods from various instruments like automatic weather stations and eddy covariance systems.

Expectation.Question: What are some anticipated challenges in collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert systems is challenging due to the poor availability of multiscale observations and the need for instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to capture diverse data types. An extensive setup, including flux observation matrices, remote sensing, and ground measurements, is necessary to address these challenges.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using SR50 ultrasonic distance meters in collecting hydrological data in dynamic and unstable riverbeds?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of SR50 ultrasonic distance meters is effective for collecting hydrological data such as river water levels with a high frequency of 30 minutes. However, in dynamic and unstable riverbeds, like the one described with frequent human disturbances and changing cross-sectional areas, the reliability of the data may be compromised. Therefore, while the method is technically sound, the environmental and anthropogenic factors pose significant challenges to data accuracy and consistency.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the potential for remote sensing technologies to enhance data collection capabilities in eco-hydrological studies of oasis-desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: Remote sensing technologies, such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and thermal imagers, offer significant potential to enhance data collection capabilities by providing multiscale and multidisciplinary observations. These technologies can capture eco-hydrological processes across diverse landscapes and improve understanding of oasis-desert interactions. However, the integration of these technologies requires careful data processing and calibration to ensure quality control and accurate representations of the observed phenomena.

Judgmental.Question: In your view, what are the main challenges in maintaining long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid regions, and how might these challenges be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges in maintaining long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid regions include ecological degradation such as river and lake drying, natural vegetation loss, land desertification, and dust storms. These environmental changes can disrupt data collection efforts and affect the stability of measurement sites. Addressing these challenges requires robust data collection and quality control methods, strategic placement of observation stations, and a comprehensive understanding of regional ecological dynamics to adaptively manage and preserve the observational infrastructure.

This includes flux observation matrices of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, supplemented by hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing and synchronical ground measurements.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand what specific challenges are faced in maintaining stable measurements of river discharge in variable desert environments.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in maintaining stable river discharge measurements in desert environments include the instability of river cross-sections due to frequent human disturbances, such as dam construction, which can lead to a lack of stable stage-discharge curves. Additionally, changes in the hydrological cross-section can cause variations in base water level measurements.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the methods used to ensure the quality and reliability of hydrometeorological data collected in semi-arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: The methods used to ensure quality and reliability include careful quality control throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation. This involves using automatic weather stations for continuous monitoring and applying a rigorous data processing and quality control procedure, which includes data collection, processing, archiving, and sharing.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data in heterogeneous landscapes and suggest potential enhancements to overcome these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Progress in collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, as mentioned in the metadata. The HiWATER experiment addresses this by using a hierarchically nested scale instrumentation to capture multiscale data. Enhancements could include expanding the network of observational stations to cover more diverse landscapes, employing more advanced remote sensing technologies, and increasing the frequency of intensive observation periods to improve data resolution and reliability.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide a detailed analysis of the data collection methods used to measure energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems and discuss their effectiveness.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems involve using eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations. These methods collect data on turbulent fluxes, radiation, soil heat flux, air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and more. The effectiveness of these methods lies in their ability to capture detailed and continuous data, providing valuable insights into the oasis–desert interactions. However, challenges such as data quality control and the need for long-term observations remain critical for ensuring data reliability.
